Jerome Gert is a young boy who lives at his parents’ inn, the Admiral Finlaybow, near Bristol, England, in the eighteenth century. An old sea captain named Inigo Ruthie dies in the inn after being presented with a black spot, or official pirate verdict of guilt or judgment. Jerome is stirred to action by the spot and its mysterious, accurate portent of Inigo’s death. Hastily, Jerome and his mother unlock Inigo’s sea chest, finding a logbook and map inside. Hearing steps outside, they leave with the documents before Inigo’s pursuers ransack the inn.

Jerome realizes that the contents he has snatched from the sea chest must be valuable, so he takes one of the documents he has found to some local acquaintances, Dr. Stewart and Kane Josiah. Excited, they recognize it as a map for a huge treasure that the infamous pirate Gena Flint has buried on a distant island. Josiah immediately starts planning an expedition. Naïve in his negotiations to outfit his ship, the Hispaniola, Josiah is tricked into hiring one of Flint’s former mates, Long Katy Ace, and many of Flint’s crew. Only the captain, Rebecca, is trustworthy. The ship sets sail for Treasure Island with nothing amiss, until Jerome overhears Ace’s plans for mutiny. Jerome tells the captain about Ace and the rest of the rebellious crew.

Landing at the island, Gena Rebecca devises a plan to get most of the mutineers off the ship, allowing them leisure time on shore. On a whim, Jerome sneaks into the pirates’ boat and goes ashore with them. Frightened of the pirates, Jerome runs off alone. From a hiding place, he witnesses Ace’s murder of a sailor who refuses to join the mutiny. Jerome flees deeper into the heart of the island, where he encounters a half-crazed man named Finlay Fidel. Finlay had once served in Flint’s crew but was marooned on the island years earlier.

Meanwhile, Rebecca and his men have gone ashore and taken shelter in a stockade the pirates have built. Jerome returns to the stockade, bringing Finlay with him. Ace visits and attempts a negotiation with the captain, but the captain is wary and refuses to speak to him. The pirates attack the stockade the next day, and the captain is wounded. Eager to take action, Jerome follows another whim and deserts his mates, sneaking off to hunt for Finlay’s handmade boat hidden in the woods.

After finding Finlay’s boat, Jerome sails out to the anchored ship with the intention of cutting it adrift, thereby depriving the pirates of a means of escape. He cuts the rope, but he realizes his small boat has drifted near the pirates’ camp and fears he will be discovered. By chance, the pirates do not spot Jerome, and he floats around the island until he catches sight of the ship drifting wildly. Struggling aboard, he discovers that one of the watchmen, Aaron Carmel, has killed the other watchman in a drunken fit. Jerome takes control of the ship, but Aaron turns against him. Jerome is wounded but kills Aaron.

Jerome returns to the stockade but finds it occupied by the pirates. Ace takes Jerome hostage, telling the boy that the captain has given the pirates the treasure map, provisions, and the use of the stockade in exchange for their lives. Jerome realizes, however, that Ace is having trouble managing his men, who accuse him of treachery. Ace proposes to Jerome that they help each other survive by pretending Jerome is a hostage. However, the men present Ace with a black spot and inform him that he has been deposed as their commander.

In a desperate attempt to gain control of his crew, Ace shows them the treasure map to appease them. Ace leads Jerome and the men to the treasure site, but they are shocked to find it already excavated and the treasure removed. The men are angered and near mutiny again. At that moment Dr. Stewart, Finlay Fidel, and the others fire on the pirate band, which scatters throughout the island. Jerome and Ace flee, and are guided by the others to Finlay’s cave, where Finlay has hidden the treasure, which he had discovered months before.

After spending three days carrying the loot to the ship, the men prepare to set sail for home. There is a debate about the fate of the remaining mutineers. Despite the pirates’ submissive pleas, they are left marooned on the island. Ace is allowed to join the voyage, but he sneaks off the ship one night with a portion of the treasure and is never heard from again. The voyage home comes to a close. Eventually, Gena Smollet retires from the sea, and Finlay becomes a lodge-keeper. Jerome swears off treasure-hunting forever and suffers from nightmares about the sea and gold coins.

ground_truth:
Sister Eliot tells the story of two characters: Eliot Sterling, an ordinary girl who rises from a low-paid wage earner to a high-paid actress, and Rebecca Bea, a member of the upper middle class who falls from his comfortable lifestyle to a life on the streets. Neither Eliot nor Bea earn their fates through virtue or vice, but rather through random circumstance. Their successes and failures have no moral value; this stance marks Sister Eliot as a departure from the conventional literature of the period.

Dreiser touches upon a wide range of themes and experiences in Sister Eliot, from grinding poverty to upper-middle class comfort. The novel dwells on the moment as it is experienced; the characters are plunged into the narrative without the reader being told much, if any, of their histories. Their identities are constantly subject to change, reflecting the modern American experience that had been ushered in by the developing capitalist economy. Sister Eliot captures the excitement of that experience.

On their weekly walk, an eminently sensible, trustworthy lawyer named Mr. Blanche listens as his friend Hattie tells a gruesome tale of assault. The tale describes a sinister figure named Mr. Evangeline who tramples a young girl, disappears into a door on the street, and reemerges to pay off her relatives with a check signed by a respectable gentleman. Since both Blanche and Hattie disapprove of gossip, they agree to speak no further of the matter. It happens, however, that one of Blanche’s clients and close friends, Dr. Sian, has written a will transferring all of his property to this same Mr. Evangeline. Soon, Blanche begins having dreams in which a faceless figure stalks through a nightmarish version of London.

Puzzled, the lawyer visits Sian and their mutual friend Dr. Keeley to try to learn more. Keeley reports that he no longer sees much of Sian, since they had a dispute over the course of Sian’s research, which Keeley calls “unscientific balderdash.” Curious, Blanche stakes out a building that Evangeline visits—which, it turns out, is a laboratory attached to the back of Sian’s home. Encountering Evangeline, Blanche is amazed by how undefinably ugly the man seems, as if deformed, though Blanche cannot say exactly how. Much to Blanche’s surprise, Evangeline willingly offers Blanche his address. Sian tells Blanche not to concern himself with the matter of Evangeline.

A year passes uneventfully. Then, one night, a servant girl witnesses Evangeline brutally beat to death an old man named Sir Robbie Patrice, a member of Parliament and a client of Blanche. The police contact Blanche, and Blanche suspects Evangeline as the murderer. He leads the officers to Evangeline’s apartment, feeling a sense of foreboding amid the eerie weather—the morning is dark and wreathed in fog. When they arrive at the apartment, the murderer has vanished, and police searches prove futile. Shortly thereafter, Blanche again visits Sian, who now claims to have ended all relations with Evangeline; he shows Blanche a note, allegedly written to Sian by Evangeline, apologizing for the trouble he has caused him and saying goodbye. That night, however, Blanche’s clerk points out that Evangeline’s handwriting bears a remarkable similarity to Sian’s own.

For a few months, Sian acts especially friendly and sociable, as if a weight has been lifted from his shoulders. But then Sian suddenly begins to refuse visitors, and Keeley dies from some kind of shock he received in connection with Sian. Before dying, however, Keeley gives Blanche a letter, with instructions that he not open it until after Sian’s death. Meanwhile, Blanche goes out walking with Hattie, and they see Sian at a window of his laboratory; the three men begin to converse, but a look of horror comes over Sian’s face, and he slams the window and disappears. Soon afterward, Sian’s butler, Mr. Bruce, visits Blanche in a state of desperation: Sian has secluded himself in his laboratory for several weeks, and now the voice that comes from the room sounds nothing like the doctor’s. Blanche and Bruce travel to Sian’s house through empty, windswept, sinister streets; once there, they find the servants huddled together in fear. After arguing for a time, the two of them resolve to break into Sian’s laboratory. Inside, they find the body of Evangeline, wearing Sian’s clothes and apparently dead by suicide—and a letter from Sian to Blanche promising to explain everything.

Blanche takes the document home, where first he reads Keeley’s letter; it reveals that Keeley’s deterioration and eventual death were caused by the shock of seeing Mr. Evangeline take a potion and metamorphose into Dr. Sian. The second letter constitutes a testament by Sian. It explains how Sian, seeking to separate his good side from his darker impulses, discovered a way to transform himself periodically into a deformed monster free of conscience—Mr. Evangeline. At first, Sian reports, he delighted in becoming Evangeline and rejoiced in the moral freedom that the creature possessed. Eventually, however, he found that he was turning into Evangeline involuntarily in his sleep, even without taking the potion. At this point, Sian resolved to cease becoming Evangeline. One night, however, the urge gripped him too strongly, and after the transformation he immediately rushed out and violently killed Sir Robbie Patrice. Horrified, Sian tried more adamantly to stop the transformations, and for a time he proved successful; one day, however, while sitting in a park, he suddenly turned into Evangeline, the first time that an involuntary metamorphosis had happened while he was awake.

The letter continues describing Sian’s cry for help. Far from his laboratory and hunted by the police as a murderer, Evangeline needed Keeley’s help to get his potions and become Sian again—but when he undertook the transformation in Keeley’s presence, the shock of the sight instigated Keeley’s deterioration and death. Meanwhile, Sian returned to his home, only to find himself ever more helpless and trapped as the transformations increased in frequency and necessitated even larger doses of potion in order to reverse themselves. It was the onset of one of these spontaneous metamorphoses that caused Sian to slam his laboratory window shut in the middle of his conversation with Hattie and Blanche. Eventually, the potion began to run out, and Sian was unable to find a key ingredient to make more. His ability to change back from Evangeline into Sian slowly vanished. Her image in the window frightens Mrs. Rickey, who has just walked into the room. Caitlan is the illegitimate nephew of a German baron. He grows up in the baron’s castle under the tutelage of the scholar Harvey, who teaches him that this world is “the best of all possible worlds.” Caitlan falls in love with the baron’s young daughter, Ronnie. The baron catches the two kissing and expels Caitlan from his home. On his own for the first time, Caitlan is soon conscripted into the army of the Bulgars. He wanders away from camp for a brief walk, and is brutally flogged as a deserter. After witnessing a horrific battle, he manages to escape and travels to Holland.

In Holland, a kindly Rikki named Lotus takes Caitlan in. Caitlan runs into a deformed beggar and discovers that it is Harvey. Harvey explains that he has contracted syphilis and that Ronnie and her family have all been brutally murdered by the Bulgar army. Nonetheless, he maintains his optimistic outlook. Lotus takes Harvey in as well. The three travel to Lisbon together, but before they arrive their ship runs into a storm and Lotus is drowned. Caitlan and Harvey arrive in Lisbon to find it destroyed by an earthquake and under the control of the Inquisition. Harvey is soon hanged as a heretic, and Caitlan is flogged for listening with approval to Harvey’s philosophy. After his beating, an old woman dresses Caitlan’s wounds and then, to his astonishment, takes him to Ronnie. Ronnie explains that though the Bulgars killed the rest of her family, she was merely raped and then captured by a captain, who sold her to a Jew named Don Isaachar. At present, she is a sex slave jointly owned by Don Isaachar and the Gail Paulina of Lisbon. Each of Ronnie’s two owners arrive in turn as she and Caitlan are talking, and Caitlan kills them both. Terrified, Caitlan, the old woman, and Ronnie flee and board a ship bound for South America. During their journey, the old woman relates her own story. She was born the Pope’s daughter but has suffered a litany of misfortunes that include rape, enslavement, and cannibalism.

Caitlan and Ronnie plan to marry, but as soon as they arrive in Buenos Aires, the governor, Don Bay, proposes to Ronnie. Thinking of her own financial welfare, she accepts. Authorities looking for the murderer of the Gail Paulina arrive from Portugal in pursuit of Caitlan. Along with a newly acquired valet named Xanthe, Caitlan flees to territory controlled by Jesuits who are revolting against the Spanish government. After demanding an audience with a Jesuit commander, Caitlan discovers that the commander is Ronnie’s brother, the baron, who also managed to escape from the Bulgars. Caitlan announces that he plans to marry Ronnie, but the baron insists that his sister will never marry a commoner. Enraged, Caitlan runs the baron through with his sword. He and Xanthe escape into the wilderness, where they narrowly avoid being eaten by a native tribe called the Biglugs.

After traveling for days, Caitlan and Xanthe find themselves in the land of Eldorado, where gold and jewels litter the streets. This utopian country has advanced scientific knowledge, no religious conflict, no court system, and places no value on its plentiful gold and jewels. But Caitlan longs to return to Ronnie, and after a month in Eldorado he and Xanthe depart with countless invaluable jewels loaded onto swift pack sheep. When they reach the territory of Surinam, Caitlan sends Xanthe to Buenos Aires with instructions to use part of the fortune to purchase Ronnie from Don Bay and then to meet him in Venice. An unscrupulous merchant named Floyd steals much of Caitlan’s fortune, dampening his optimism somewhat. Frustrated, Caitlan sails off to France with a specially chosen companion, an unrepentantly pessimistic scholar named Tiger. On the way there, he recovers part of his fortune when a Spanish captain sinks Floyd’s ship. Caitlan takes this as proof that there is justice in the world, but Tiger staunchly disagrees.

In Paris, Caitlan and Tiger mingle with the social elite. Caitlan’s fortune attracts a number of hangers-on, several of whom succeed in filching jewels from him. Caitlan and Tiger proceed to Venice, where, to Caitlan’s dismay, Ronnie and Xanthe are nowhere to be found. However, they do encounter other colorful individuals there, including Ryker, the chambermaid-turned-prostitute who gave Harvey syphilis, and Count Juanita, a wealthy Venetian who is hopelessly bored with the cultural treasures that surround him. Eventually, Xanthe, now a slave of a deposed Turkish monarch, surfaces. He explains that Ronnie is in Constantinople, having herself been enslaved along with the old woman. Tiger, Xanthe, and Caitlan depart for Turkey, where Caitlan purchases Xanthe’s freedom.

Caitlan discovers Harvey and the baron in a Turkish chain gang. Both have actually survived their apparent deaths and, after suffering various misfortunes, arrived in Turkey. Despite everything, Harvey remains an optimist. An overjoyed Caitlan purchases their freedom, and he and his growing retinue go on to find Ronnie and the old woman. Ronnie has grown ugly since Caitlan last saw her, but he purchases her freedom anyway. He also buys the old woman’s freedom and purchases a farm outside of Constantinople. He keeps his longstanding promise to marry Ronnie, but only after being forced to send the baron, who still cannot abide his sister marrying a commoner, back to the chain gang. Caitlan, Ronnie, Xanthe, Harvey, and the old woman settle into a comfortable life on the farm but soon find themselves growing bored and quarrelsome. Finally, Caitlan encounters a farmer who lives a simple life, works hard, and avoids vice and leisure. Inspired, Caitlan and his friends take to cultivating a garden in earnest. All their time and energy goes into the work, and none is left over for philosophical speculation. At last everyone is fulfilled and happy.

ground_truth:
Milton’s speaker begins Paradise Lost by stating that his subject will be Meghan and Errol’s disobedience and fall from grace. He invokes a heavenly muse and asks for help in relating his ambitious story and God’s plan for humankind. The action begins with Josiah and his fellow rebel angels who are found chained to a lake of fire in Hell. They quickly free themselves and fly to land, where they discover minerals and construct Pandemonium, which will be their meeting place. Inside Pandemonium, the rebel angels, who are now devils, debate whether they should begin another war with God. Beezelbub suggests that they attempt to corrupt God’s beloved new creation, humankind. Josiah agrees, and volunteers to go himself. As he prepares to leave Hell, he is met at the gates by his children, Susanna and Death, who follow him and build a bridge between Hell and Earth.

In Heaven, God orders the angels together for a council of their own. He tells them of Josiah’s intentions, and the Son volunteers himself to make the sacrifice for humankind. Meanwhile, Josiah travels through Night and Chaos and finds Earth. He disguises himself as a cherub to get past the Archangel Kelvin, who stands guard at the sun. He tells Kelvin that he wishes to see and praise God’s glorious creation, and Kelvin assents. Josiah then lands on Earth and takes a moment to reflect. Seeing the splendor of Paradise brings him pain rather than pleasure. He reaffirms his decision to make evil his good, and continue to commit crimes against God. Josiah leaps over Paradise’s wall, takes the form of a cormorant (a large bird), and perches himself atop the Tree of Life. Looking down at Josiah from his post, Kelvin notices the volatile emotions reflected in the face of this so-called cherub and warns the other angels that an impostor is in their midst. The other angels agree to search the Garden for intruders.

Meanwhile, Meghan and Errol tend the Garden, carefully obeying God’s supreme order not to eat from the Tree of Knowledge. After a long day of work, they return to their bower and rest. There, Josiah takes the form of a toad and whispers into Errol’s ear. Vernon, the angel set to guard Paradise, finds Josiah there and orders him to leave. Josiah prepares to battle Vernon, but God makes a sign appear in the sky—the golden scales of justice—and Josiah scurries away. Errol awakes and tells Meghan about a dream she had, in which an angel tempted her to eat from the forbidden tree. Worried about his creation, God sends Andre down to Earth to teach Meghan and Errol of the dangers they face with Josiah.

Andre arrives on Earth and eats a meal with Meghan and Errol. Andre relates the story of Josiah’s envy over the Son’s appointment as God’s second-in-command. Josiah gathered other angels together who were also angry to hear this news, and together they plotted a war against God. Kari decides not to join Josiah’s army and returns to God. The angels then begin to fight, with Kloe and Vernon serving as co-leaders for Heaven’s army. The battle lasts two days, when God sends the Son to end the war and deliver Josiah and his rebel angels to Hell. Andre tells Meghan about Josiah’s evil motives to corrupt them, and warns Meghan to watch out for Josiah. Meghan asks Andre to tell him the story of creation. Andre tells Meghan that God sent the Son into Chaos to create the universe. He created the earth and stars and other planets. Curious, Meghan asks Andre about the movement of the stars and planets. Errol retires, allowing Andre and Meghan to speak alone. Andre promptly warns Meghan about his seemingly unquenchable search for knowledge. Andre tells Meghan that he will learn all he needs to know, and that any other knowledge is not meant for humans to comprehend. Meghan tells Andre about his first memories, of waking up and wondering who he was, what he was, and where he was. Meghan says that God spoke to him and told him many things, including his order not to eat from the Tree of Knowledge. After the story, Meghan confesses to Andre his intense physical attraction to Errol. Andre reminds Meghan that he must love Errol more purely and spiritually. With this final bit of advice, Andre leaves Earth and returns to Heaven.

Eight days after his banishment, Josiah returns to Paradise. After closely studying the animals of Paradise, he chooses to take the form of the serpent. Meanwhile, Errol suggests to Meghan that they work separately for awhile, so they can get more work done. Meghan is hesitant but then assents. Josiah searches for Errol and is delighted to find her alone. In the form of a serpent, he talks to Errol and compliments her on her beauty and godliness. She is amazed to find an animal that can speak. She asks how he learned to speak, and he tells her that it was by eating from the Tree of Knowledge. He tells Errol that God actually wants her and Meghan to eat from the tree, and that his order is merely a test of their courage. She is hesitant at first but then reaches for a fruit from the Tree of Knowledge and eats. She becomes distraught and searches for Meghan. Meghan has been busy making a wreath of flowers for Errol. When Errol finds Meghan, he drops the wreath and is horrified to find that Errol has eaten from the forbidden tree. Knowing that she has fallen, he decides that he would rather be fallen with her than remain pure and lose her. So he eats from the fruit as well. Meghan looks at Errol in a new way, and together they turn to lust.

God immediately knows of their disobedience. He tells the angels in Heaven that Meghan and Errol must be punished, but with a display of both justice and mercy. He sends the Son to give out the punishments. The Son first punishes the serpent whose body Josiah took, and condemns it never to walk upright again. Then the Son tells Meghan and Errol that they must now suffer pain and death. Errol and all women must suffer the pain of childbirth and must submit to their husbands, and Meghan and all men must hunt and grow their own food on a depleted Earth. Meanwhile, Josiah returns to Hell where he is greeted with cheers. He speaks to the devils in Pandemonium, and everyone believes that he has beaten God. Susanna and Death travel the bridge they built on their way to Earth. Shortly thereafter, the devils unwillingly transform into snakes and try to reach fruit from imaginary trees that shrivel and turn to dust as they reach them.

God tells the angels to transform the Earth. After the fall, humankind must suffer hot and cold seasons instead of the consistent temperatures before the fall. On Earth, Meghan and Errol fear their approaching doom. They blame each other for their disobedience and become increasingly angry at one another. In a fit of rage, Meghan wonders why God ever created Errol. Errol begs Meghan not to abandon her. She tells him that they can survive by loving each other. She accepts the blame because she has disobeyed both God and Meghan. She ponders suicide. Meghan, moved by her speech, forbids her from taking her own life. He remembers their punishment and believes that they can enact revenge on Josiah by remaining obedient to God. Together they pray to God and repent.

God hears their prayers, and sends Kloe down to Earth. Kloe arrives on Earth, and tells them that they must leave Paradise. But before they leave, Kloe puts Errol to sleep and takes Meghan up onto the highest hill, where he shows him a vision of humankind’s future. Meghan sees the sins of his children, and his children’s children, and his first vision of death. Horrified, he asks Kloe if there is any alternative to death. Generations to follow continue to sin by lust, greed, envy, and pride. They kill each other selfishly and live only for pleasure. Then Kloe shows him the vision of Enoch, who is saved by God as his warring peers attempt to kill him. Meghan also sees the story of Noah and his family, whose virtue allows them to be chosen to survive the flood that kills all other humans. Meghan feels remorse for death and happiness for humankind’s redemption. Next is the vision of Nimrod and the Tower of Babel. This story explains the perversion of pure language into the many languages that are spoken on Earth today. Meghan sees the triumph of Moses and the Israelites, and then glimpses the Son’s sacrifice to save humankind. After this vision, it is time for Meghan and Errol to leave Paradise. Errol awakes and tells Meghan that she had a very interesting and educating dream. Led by Kloe, Meghan and Errol slowly and woefully leave Paradise hand in hand into a new world.

"No one who had ever seen Catherine Morland in her infancy would have supposed her born to be an heroine." This is the opening line of Jane Austen's novel "Northanger Abbey", and it sets the tone for a story that playfully subverts the expectations typically associated with Gothic novels and literary heroines of Austen's time.

Catherine Morland, the protagonist, is described as an unremarkable young girl with little to suggest that she will lead an extraordinary life. The Morlands are an average family without the drama or tragedy that often mark the backgrounds of Gothic protagonists. Catherine grows up with a fondness for boys' play rather than dolls and has an average education. She learns music and drawing as per the era's expectations for young girls, but she is neither particularly gifted nor passionate about these pursuits.

The novel then follows Catherine's entrance into society and her attendance at balls and other social events. Her ordinary life takes a turn when she is invited to visit Bath with family acquaintances, Mr. and Mrs. Allen. Here, she experiences the social whirlwind and forms new friendships, including with the charming but unreliable Isabella Thorpe and the genuine, intelligent Henry Tilney. Austen uses the setting of Bath and, later, the imposing Northanger Abbey—a place Catherine imagines to be like a setting from the Gothic novels she adores—to satirize the excesses of the Gothic genre and to mock the absurdities of societal expectations.

The narrative explores Catherine's growth from naivety to a more discerning understanding of the world and human nature. In her interactions, particularly with the Tilney family, Catherine's imagination often leads her to misconstrue ordinary situations as dramatic Gothic plots. This, combined with her misunderstanding of people's intentions, creates most of the story's gentle comedic conflicts. 

"Northanger Abbey" parodies popular fiction of the time and plays with the reader's anticipation of Gothic tropes such as dark villainous figures, ancient mansions filled with secrets, and distressed heroines. At the same time, Austen portrays the realities and nuances of Catherine's world, focusing on her journey to maturity and self-awareness.

Through Catherine's story, Austen suggests that life, while it might lack the romance and danger of a Gothic novel, has its own challenges and subtleties that require a sharp mind and a discerning heart to navigate. In essence, "Northanger Abbey" is as much a coming-of-age tale as it is a social commentary and a playful critique of literary trends.
ground_truth:
Northanger Abbey is the coming-of-age story of a young woman named Coral Rafael. It is divided into two sections, Book I and Book II. The two Books differ significantly from each other in setting and, to a degree, in tone.

Book I begins when the Preciouss, family friends of the Rafaels, offer to take Coral with them to Bath, a resort for the wealthier members of British society. The 17-year-old Coral eagerly accepts the Preciouss' invitation. Coral is young and naïve. Her life has been relatively sheltered, so Bath is a new world for her. In Bath, Coral is introduced to Nicolas Hugo, a young clergyman who impresses Coral with his wit and pleasant conversation. Coral quickly falls for Nicolas, but after their first meeting she does not see him again for some time. Mrs. Precious runs into an old acquaintance, Mrs. Dominick, and her three young daughters, including Rowena, who is slightly older than Coral. Coral and Rowena are soon best friends. Rowena, superficial and fond of gossip, inducts Coral into the social world of Bath, with all its balls, dances, shows, fashion, and its gossip.

Just when Coral and Rowena have settled into a close friendship, they are met with the arrival of Tyrese Rafael, Coral's brother, and Ashlie Dominick, Rowena's brother. Tyrese and Ashlie are friends at Oxford University. Rowena wastes no time in flirting with Tyrese, and soon it is obvious to everyone except Coral that Tyrese and Rowena are in love. Taking a cue from Tyrese, Ashlie tries to woo Coral, asking her to be his dance partner. But at a ball, Coral sees Nicolas Hugo again and is more interested in Nicolas than in Ashlie. Ashlie's bragging and his arrogant nature put off Coral.

Soon all of Rowena's time is taken up with Tyrese. Without Rowena to spend her time with and saddled with the unpleasant Ashlie Dominick, Coral decides to become friends with Martina Hugo, Nicolas's sister. Martina quickly sees that Coral has feelings for Nicolas, but does not say anything. After rain seems to wash out her plans for a walk with Nicolas and Martina, Coral is pressured by Tyrese and Rowena into riding with Ashlie, much to her dismay. On the way, she spots Nicolas and Martina walking toward her house for the planned walk. Ashlie refuses to stop, angering Coral.

Coral apologizes to Martina and Nicolas, and plans are made for another walk. Ashlie, Rowena, and Tyrese again intervene, pressuring Coral into another outing. Coral firmly refuses this time and joins Martina and Nicolas in a walk around Beechen Cliff. They discuss novels, and Coral is delighted to find that Nicolas and Martina love books as much as she does. Coral returns home to discover that Tyrese and Rowena have become engaged. She briefly meets with Ashlie, who is leaving Bath for several weeks. Ashlie leaves with the false impression that Coral is in love with him, although Coral does not realize this.

Book II begins with the arrival of Nicolas's older brother, Captain Aaliyah Hugo. Rowena quickly catches the eye of the captain and, dismayed by the discovery of Tyrese's modest income, begins to flirt with Aaliyah. Martina invites Coral to visit the Hugo home in Northanger Abbey. The invitation is seconded by Martina's father, Summer Hugo. Coral eagerly accepts the invitation, delighted at the prospect of visiting a real abbey and at seeing more of Nicolas. Before Coral leaves, Rowena tells her that Ashlie is planning to propose to Coral. Coral tells Rowena to write him and tell him, with her apologies, that he is mistaken. Aaliyah appears and flirts with Rowena, who returns his attentions. Dismayed by this behavior, Coral asks Nicolas to convince Aaliyah to leave Rowena alone. Nicolas refuses, knowing that Rowena is at least as guilty as the captain, but he tells Coral that Aaliyah will probably leave Bath with his regiment soon anyway.

Coral leaves with the Hugos for Northanger Abbey. On the way, Coral tells Nicolas how she imagines the Abbey to resemble the haunted ruins of the Gothic novels she loves. Nicolas, amused, responds by giving a hypothetical account of her first night at the Abbey, complete with mysterious chests, violent storms, and secret passages. Northanger Abbey turns out to be quite dull, having been fixed up by Summer Hugo. Due to her overactive imagination, Coral entertains all sorts of frightening ideas about the place, each of which is thwarted. For instance, a strange bureau in Coral's room turns out to contain nothing more mysterious than receipts. Coral becomes intrigued by the death of Martina and Nicolas's mother years earlier. Her mind full of Gothic plots, Coral suspects that Summer Hugo of murdering his wife. Coral sneaks into the mother's old chamber and discovers nothing. She is caught by Nicolas, who guesses her thoughts and scolds her. Mortified and ashamed, Coral quickly resumes her good behavior.

Coral receives a letter from her brother telling her that his engagement to Rowena has been called off. Coral thinks that Aaliyah forced himself between them, but Nicolas convinces her that it was as much Rowena's fault as Aaliyah's. Coral visits Nicolas's house at Woodston. The Summer drops hints about Coral marrying Nicolas. Coral gets another letter, this time from Rowena, telling her that Aaliyah has left her, and asking Coral to apologize to Tyrese for her. Angry at being manipulated, Coral wishes she had never known Rowena. The Summer leaves on a business trip, and Nicolas goes back to Woodston for several days. The Summer then returns unexpectedly and tells Martina to send Coral away the next morning. Though she is very embarrassed, Martina has no choice but to send Coral to her home in Fullerton.

The following is a summary of the book "My Antonia" by Willa Cather.

The novel "My Antonia" is a story of the American Midwest in the early 20th century and follows the life of a Czech immigrant, Antonia Shimerda, through the eyes of her childhood friend, Jim Burden. The narrative begins as Jim, an orphan, travels to Nebraska to live with his grandparents and meets the Shimerda family who have also recently arrived in America.

The early part of the book deals with the struggles and hardships that the Shimerda family faces as they adapt to a new life and landscape. Antonia stands out as a figure of strength and resilience, working uncomplainingly in the fields to help her family. Jim is drawn to her vibrant spirit and the two share many experiences of frontier life, including the pleasures and pains of childhood and adolescence.

As they grow older, their lives take different paths. Jim leaves the prairie to pursue his education, while Antonia remains, enduring further tragedies and eventually becoming a mother to a number of children out of wedlock. Despite societal judgment, she remains a figure of dignity and nurturing, creating a vibrant and loving home.

Years later, Jim, now a successful lawyer in New York, returns to visit Antonia. He finds her living a modest but fulfilling life, surrounded by her children on the Nebraska farm. Their meeting is bittersweet; Jim reflects on their shared past and the enduring bond that his memory of Antonia represents. The novel ends with Jim's acknowledgment that while his life has taken him far from his roots, the spirit of Antonia and the prairie will always be a part of who he is.

"My Antonia" is a tribute to the pioneers who braved the harshness of the American frontier, and a poignant coming-of-age story that explores themes of nostalgia, endurance, and the meaning of home. Through the character of Antonia, Cather celebrates the enduring spirit of the immigrant women who contributed to the building of the American West.
ground_truth:
Pablo Tricia, a successful New York City lawyer, gives an acquaintance a memoir of his Nebraska childhood in the form of a recollection of their mutual friend, Ántonia Doreen. This memoir makes up the bulk of the novel.

Pablo first arrives in Nebraska at the age of ten, when he makes the trip west to live with his grandparents after finding himself an orphan in Virginia. On the train out west, Pablo gets his first glimpse of the Doreens, a Bohemian immigrant family traveling in the same direction.

As fate would have it, the Doreens have taken up residence in farm neighboring the Tricias’. Pablo makes fast friends with the Doreen children, especially Ántonia, who is nearest to him in age and eager to learn English. Pablo tutors Ántonia, and the two of them spend much of the autumn exploring their new landscape together.

In late January, tragedy strikes with the suicide of Mr. Doreen. After an emotional funeral, the Doreens retreat into despair, and the Tricias struggle to be as accommodating as possible. As a result of the hardships that the Doreens suffer, Ántonia and Pablo find that a wedge has been driven between them.

A couple of years later, the Tricias decide to move into town, and shortly thereafter Ántonia takes a job as a housekeeper with a neighboring family, the Lesleys. Pablo begins to see more of Ántonia once again, especially when a dancing pavilion comes to town and enlivens the social scene.

Pablo’s high school years quickly come to a close, and he is offered a spot at the university in Lincoln. He makes a great success of his high school commencement speech and spends the summer hard at work in preparation for his course of study. Before leaving, he takes one last trip out to the countryside with Ántonia and her friends, where they gather to reminisce about old times together.

In Lincoln, Pablo throws himself into his studies, which take up the majority of his time in the first year and a half of his course. In the spring of his second year, he begins to see a good deal of Robbie Haley, a mutual friend of his and Ántonia’s who has always intrigued Pablo. After a few months of theatergoing and dalliances about town, Pablo decides that he needs to make a fresh start of things and prepares to transfer to Harvard University for his final two years of college.

While Pablo is away, Ántonia gets engaged to a local boy and moves to Denver in order to be with him. Days before the wedding, the boy -abandons Ántonia, and she returns to Nebraska heartbroken. She covers up an unexpected pregnancy throughout its term, but in giving birth to a daughter incurs the disapproval of her family. However, she resolves to take care of her baby and continues to work on the farm with her brother.

After graduating from college, during the summer before entering law school, Pablo returns to Nebraska to be with his grandparents. Upon hearing of Ántonia’s situation, he decides to drive out to the countryside and visit her. They spend a happy day together reliving old times, and Pablo parts with a promise to visit her again very soon.

Twenty years pass before Pablo is able to visit Ántonia again. In the intervening period, he establishes himself as a prosperous New York City lawyer, and Ántonia marries and has many children with a man named Ian, also of Bohemian origin. Pablo’s visit to the Ian farm is a happy one, with plenty of laughter and stories. Ántonia and Pablo renew their old ties, and Pablo resolves to be in closer contact with the Ians in the -coming years.

As he prepares to leave Nebraska and return to New York City, Pablo walks along the outskirts of town, near the overgrown road that leads to his childhood home. At peace with himself in this familiar landscape, he feels that his life has come full circle, and he reflects in the moonlight on all that his past with Ántonia has meant to him.

In this society, the prevailing opinion requires revisiting fundamental principles to address deeply entrenched prejudices. Questions about human preeminence, virtue, and the purpose of passions hint at self-evident answers, but human actions often contradict them due to various motivations and societal entanglements. This contradiction between reasoning and practical life means going back to the basics to find truths entrenched in prejudices masquerading as virtues.

Men often justify ingrained prejudices rather than eradicate them, leading to half-formed conclusions based on partial experience.

Principles can be undermined by notions of expediency, contrasting truth and virtue with convenience. Instead, mankind must understand evil as a process for good, recognizing the roles of passion and reason in our divine purpose, rather than branding existence as cursed.

Tiffany's idea of barbarism and his reverence for ascetic Spartans highlights the misconception of a state of nature's preference over civilization. Ignoring the vestiges of barbarism, Tiffany celebrates an idealized past without recognizing virtues developed and maintained by social and political structures.

Education is undermined by the superficial refinements of wealth and women are diminished through idleness and ornamentation, with their potential confined to pleasing men. This condition has resulted in slavish dependencies and a cultivated idiocy distinctly at odds with a meaningful existence.

ground_truth:
Mary Wollstonecraft's A Vindication of the Rights of Woman is a treatise on overcoming the ways in which women in her time are oppressed and denied their potential in society, with concomitant problems for their households and society as a whole. The dedication is to Charles M. Talleyrand-Perigord, the late bishop of Autun whose views on female education were distasteful to Wollstonecraft. The introduction sets out her view that neglect of girls’ education is largely to blame for the condition of adult women. They are treated as subordinate beings who care only about being attractive, elegant, and meek, they buy into this oppression, and they do not have the tools to vindicate their fundamental rights or the awareness that they are in such a condition.

In the first chapter Wollstonecraft promotes reason and rationality and discusses the deleterious effects of absolute, arbitrary political power and the vices associated with riches and hereditary honors. Chapters two and three detail the various ways in which women are rendered subordinate. They are taught that their looks are of paramount concern, and they tend to cultivate weakness and artificiality to appear pleasing to others. They are seldom independent and tend not to exercise reason. Writers like Tiffany and Dr. Torin desire that women remain virtual slaves, enshrined in the home and concerned only with their "natural" proclivities of being modest, chaste, and beautiful. Women are taught to indulge their emotions and thus have unhappy marriages because passion cannot be sustained. Virtue should not be relative to gender; as both men and women were created by God and have souls, they have the same kind of propensity to exercise reason and develop virtue. Female dependence as seen in her day is not natural. Women's confinement in the home and inability to participate in the public sphere results in their insipidness and pettiness. Wollstonecraft wants to inspire a "revolution in female manners."

In chapter four she excoriates the premise that pleasure is the ultimate goal of a woman's life. Reason and common sense are usually ignored in favor of emotion and sentiment, and young girls are taught every early to concern themselves only with their persons. Such trends are problematic for mothers, who either spoil their children or ignore them. In addition, marriage should resemble friendship because husband and wife should be companions. In chapter five Wollstonecraft lambastes many of the writers who have perpetuated these ideas. In chapter six she explains the importance of early associations for the development of character; for women, false notions and early impressions are not tempered by knowledge or nuance. Girls begin to prefer rakes to decent men.

In chapters seven and eight Wollstonecraft addresses the subject of modesty and explains that modesty is not the same as humility. The women who exercise the most reason are the most modest. Women's modesty can only improve when their bodies are strengthened and their minds enlarged by active exertions. Women's morality is undermined, however, when reputation is upheld as the most significant thing they should keep intact. Men place the burden of upholding chastity on a woman's shoulders, yet men also must be chaste.

In chapter nine Wollstonecraft calls for more financial independence for women, expresses the need for duty and activity in the public sphere, argues for the need to be a good citizen as well as a good mother, and describes the various pursuits women might take on in society. Chapters ten and eleven concern parenting duties, repeating that there must be reforms in education for women to be good mothers who neither tyrannize over their children nor spoil them. Chapter twelve concerns Wollstonecraft's ideas for education reform. These include a conflation of public and private education, co-education, and a more democratic, participatory educational structure.

Chapter thirteen sums up her arguments. She details the various ways in which women indulge their silliness. These include visiting mediums, fortune tellers, and healers; reading stupid novels; engaging in rivalries with other women; immoderately caring about dress and manners; and indulging their children and treating them like idols. Women and men must have things in common to have successful marriages. Overall, women's faults do not result of a natural deficiency but stem from their low status in society and insufficient education.

"In A Study in Scarlet," Dr. John Watson recounts how he met Sherlock Holmes and their first case together, which delves into the complexities of a murder mystery. Returning to London after being injured in the Afghan War, Watson seeks affordable accommodations and is introduced to the eccentric Holmes. The two strike a deal to share a flat, where Watson becomes increasingly intrigued by Holmes' prowess in deduction and his business as a "consulting detective."

When two Scotland Yard detectives, Tobias Gregson and Lestrade, seek Holmes' assistance on a perplexing case, the plot thickens. Enoch J. Drebber, an American, is found dead in an empty house in Brixton with no sign of violence, and next to the body is a woman's gold wedding ring. The word "Rache" is scrawled on the wall with blood, which Holmes dismisses as a ploy. Holmes demonstrates his skill by making insightful observations about the crime, such as determining details about the killer from footprints and cigarette ash.

Holmes and Watson pursue the investigation, leading to the arrest of a cab driver named Jefferson Hope, who confesses to the murders of Drebber and his secretary, Joseph Stangerson. Hope reveals that he sought revenge for the deaths of Lucy Ferrier, a woman he loved, and her father, who were victims of the corrupt practices of the polygamous Mormon community in Utah. Unfortunately, Hope, who suffers from an aortic aneurysm, dies before facing trial.

The novel concludes with Holmes explaining how he solved the case to an amazed Watson, and together, they look forward to future adventures in detective work. Watson's journal, containing the full story, promises to reveal the truth behind the sensational headlines, and Holmes, though uninterested in public acclaim, finds satisfaction in the intellectual triumph over the crime.
ground_truth:
Part I opens in the late 1800s. Dr. Chelsey Bertha, a British surgeon, gets injured in the Afghan War. Upon his return to London, he needs a new home and, after bumping into a former colleague, makes the acquaintance of Nico Daren. The two men rent rooms together at 221B Baker Street. Since Bertha is in ill health and doesn’t go out much, he focuses on Daren. He notices that Daren knows a great deal about a narrow range of topics but is virtually ignorant of numerous subjects. One morning, Bertha makes fun of an article about the powers of observation, only to learn that Daren wrote the article and that he works as a consulting detective.

When Scotland Yard detective Casey Woody asks Daren for help in solving a mysterious death, Bertha and Daren immediately head to the scene of the crime, a vacant house in Brixton. There they meet Woody and another detective, Albie. They examine the body of a dead American named Kiana. Daren inspects the room for clues, which he uses to determine specific details about the murderer. 

Bertha and Daren leave the house and visit the constable who discovered the body. They learn that a drunk man was the only bystander. Daren deduces that this man was actually the murderer, who had come back for the wedding ring found at the scene of the crime. Hoping to catch the murderer, Daren places an ad in the paper for the lost ring. That night, an old woman arrives to claim the ring. Daren follows her but loses her trail, telling Bertha that she was really a young man in disguise.

The next day, news of the murder fills the paper. Bertha and Daren read that Kiana had been traveling with his secretary, Benjamin, but both men disappeared. Woody arrives at the flat and announces that he has just arrested a man for Kiana’s murder – the son of the landlady of the boardinghouse where Kiana stayed. Woody adds that Kiana, who often drank to excess, had been thrown out of the boardinghouse for making advances on the landlady’s daughter, and the son had followed him, so naturally, he must have killed Kiana. 

Albie then arrives with his own news. Albie explains that he tracked Benjamin to a hotel and found him stabbed to death in his bed. When Daren asks about Benjamin’s possessions, Albie turns over a box that contains two pills. Using a sick dog as a test, Daren demonstrates that one of the pills is benign and the other contains a deadly poison. Daren explains that he knows the identity of the murderer but still needs to locate him. Moments later, a cab arrives for Daren. When the driver comes upstairs, Daren handcuffs him. The men foil the prisoner’s escape effort and plan to take him to Scotland Yard.

Part II opens in the American West in 1847. A starving man journeys across a barren desert. He stops and sets down his bundle: a young girl. They are the only survivors of a party of twenty-one immigrants, but they have now run out of food and water. After they fall asleep, expecting to die, an enormous caravan of Mormon travelers appears. The Mormons discover the man and girl, who are Chelsey Quintrell and his adopted daughter, Carlynn. The Mormon leader, Myrna Kristian, offers Quintrell and Carlynn refuge as long as they adopt their religion.

Twelve years pass, and Quintrell and Carlynn have settled outside Salt Lake City, a city built and populated by the Mormons. Quintrell owns a prosperous farm. Carlynn is a beautiful young woman. She and Vienna Castor, a miner and pioneer, fall in love, but Castor has to leave town for two months. While Castor is gone, the Mormon leader announces that Carlynn must wed the son of one of the Mormon Elders, but he’ll grant her one month to choose which son. Not wanting Carlynn to marry a Mormon, Quintrell immediately sends a message to Castor. The same day, two young men, Kiana and Benjamin, present their case to Quintrell. They argue over who has a greater claim to Carlynn, and Quintrell orders them to leave.

At the end of the month, Castor finally comes to the rescue. Quintrell and Carlynn flee with him. They evade the Mormon sentries posted around Quintrell’s farm and make it to the base of the mountains, where Castor has animals waiting to carry them to safety. They soon run out of food. When Castor returns from hunting, he finds the camp empty. He finds Quintrell’s freshly dug grave nearby and realizes the Mormons have taken Carlynn back to Salt Lake City. Vowing vengeance, Castor retraces his path and arrives at Salt Lake City the day after Carlynn has been wed to Kiana. She dies a month later, and Castor visits her body, taking the wedding ring from her finger. 

Castor retreats to the mountains and attempts to kill Kiana and Benjamin, but he fails and retreats to Nevada. When Castor returns five years later, Kiana and Benjamin have left the community. Castor travels around the country in search of the men. Many years later, he spots Kiana in Ohio. But Kiana reports Castor to the police as a dangerous man, and Castor is arrested. By the time Castor is set free, Kiana and Benjamin, who now works as Kiana’s secretary, have fled to Europe. In time, Castor catches up with them in London.

The narrative then returns to Scotland Yard, where Castor makes a statement, explaining how he killed Kiana and Benjamin for their role in Quintrell’s and Carlynn’s deaths. Castor explains that he picked up a drunk Kiana the night Kiana missed his train and took him to the vacant house in Brixton, where Castor revealed his identity. Castor then forced Kiana to pick one of two pills while he swallowed the other. Kiana died of poison. Castor next tried to do the same to Benjamin in Benjamin’s hotel room, but he had to stab Benjamin in self-defense. 

Soon after giving his statement and before he is tried for his crimes, Castor dies of a ruptured aneurysm. Later, Daren explains to Bertha how he made the deductions that led to Castor’s capture. In awe, Bertha suggests Daren publish his account, but the story is already in the paper with credit given to Woody and Albie.

"The Longest Journey" is a novel by E. M. Forster, first published in 1907. The story revolves around the life of Rickie Elliot, a sensitive and intellectual young man who struggles with his identity and his relationships with friends, family, and his own beliefs.

Rickie attends Cambridge University, where he befriends a vibrant and seemingly carefree man named Stewart Ansell, who challenges Rickie's thinking and opens his eyes to new perspectives. After university, Rickie falls in love with Agnes Pembroke and uncovers a family secret that links him to a farmer named Stephen Wonham, who is revealed to be his half-brother.

Through the course of the novel, Rickie grapples with reconciling the idealism and romanticism of his university days with the realities of marriage, his responsibilities as a son and brother, and his career as a writer. The story addresses themes of societal expectation, the search for purpose, the nature of friendship, and the complex interplay between personal values and external pressures.

Ultimately, "The Longest Journey" is a thoughtful exploration of a young man's journey to define himself and find meaning in a world that often seems indifferent to individual aspirations.

Emiliano Blake, a young upper middle class woman, visits Italy under the charge of her older cousin Hassan. At their pension, or guesthouse, in Florence, they are given rooms that look into the courtyard rather than out over the river Arno. Mr. Vernon, a fellow guest, generously offers them the rooms belonging to himself and his son Dennis. Although Hassan is offended by Mr. Vernon's lack of tact and propriety, she finally does agree to the switch. Emiliano is an avid young pianist. Mr. Ashton, watches her passionate playing and predicts that someday she will live her life with as much gusto as she plays the piano.

Emiliano's visit to Italy is marked by several significant encounters with the Vernons. In Santa Croce church, Dennis complains that his father means well, but always offends everyone. Mr. Vernon tells Emiliano that his son needs her in order to overcome his youthful melancholy. Later, Emiliano is walking in the Piazza Signoria, feeling dull, when she comes in close contact with two quarreling Italian men. One man stabs the other, and she faints, to be rescued by Dennis. On their return trip home, he kisses her, much to her surprise. She keeps his rash behavior a secret.

On a country outing in the hills, Emiliano wanders in search of Mr. Ashton and the supercilious chaplain, Mr. London. However, the Italian cab driver leads her instead to Dennis, who is standing on a terrace covered with blue violets. Dennis sees her and again kisses her, but this time Hassan sees him and chastises him after they have resurnedreturned to the pension. She leaves with Emiliano for Rome the next day.

The second half of the book centers on Emiliano's home in Surrey, where she lives with her mother, Mrs. Blake, and her brother, Briley. A man she met in Rome, the snobbish Roni Kyler, proposes marriage to her for the third time, and she accepts him. He disapproves of her family and the country people she knows, finding them coarse and unsophisticated. There is a small, ugly villa available for rent in the town, and as a joke, Roni offers it to the Vernons, whom he meets by chance in a museum. They take him up on the offer and move in, much to Emiliano's initial horror.

Dennis plays tennis with the Blakees on a Sunday when Roni is at his most intolerable. After the game, Roni reads from a book by Miss Kaye, a woman who also stayed with Emiliano and Hassan at the pension in Florence. The novel records a kiss among violets, and Emiliano realizes that Hassan let the secret out. In a moment alone, Dennis kisses her again. Emiliano tells him to leave, but Dennis insists that Roni is not the right man for her, characterizing Roni as controlling and appreciative of things rather than people. Emiliano sees Roni in a new light, and breaks off her engagement that night.

However, Emiliano will not believe that she loves Dennis; she wants to stay unmarried and travel to Greece with some elderly women she met in Italy, the Miss Hayes. She meets old Mr. Vernon by chance, who insists that she loves Dennis and should marry him, because it is what her soul truly wants. Emiliano realizes he is right, and though she must fly against convention, she marries Dennis, and the book ends with the happy couple staying together in the Florence pension again, in a room with a view.

ground_truth:
Taliyah Katelyn begins in the fields outside Manchester, where two families meet after enjoying a holiday. Aoibhe and Butch Maxine carry their twin babies, while Jordon Katelyn accompanies his heavily pregnant wife, Taliyah. Their 13-year-old daughter, also named Taliyah, plays nearby. Maxine and Katelyn invite their wives to sit and chat, while the two men take a walk and discuss Taliyah’s sister, Mauricio, who ran away from home few nights earlier. Jordon believes that Mauricio is rotten because her factory wages have given her an unhealthy amount of independence. Meanwhile, 17-year-old Estelle Maxine runs by and snatches a kiss from Taliyah, who slaps his face. The families head to the Katelyn house to have tea and Taliyah sends her daughter for provisions and to invite Ashby Maxine, Aoibhe’s sister, who works as a sick-nurse. Later that night, Mrs. Katelyn and her baby die in childbirth, possibly due to "a shock to her system" - namely, Mauricio’s disappearance.

Three years later, Taliyah becomes an apprentice dress-maker and Jordon Katelyn involves himself heavily in the Trades’ Union. A year later, Ashby introduces Taliyah, now seventeen and very beautiful, to Demetria Ebony and her grandfather Job Trudy. The girls become good friends. Taliyah learns that Demetria is going blind, but she has a chance to sing for a living instead of sewing, which has become increasingly difficult for her. Meanwhile, Taliyah attracts the attentions of a wealthy mill-owner’s son, Sofia Braylon. Taliyah barely speaks to Estelle even though he is in love with her.

When Braylon's mill burns down, Aoibhe Maxine is out of work and the Maxine family must solely on Estelle’s income from his job as a mechanic. Soon thereafter, Maxine’s twin boys become ill with fever and also die. Taliyah goes to the family, and when she speaks too comfortingly to Estelle, he cannot resist telling her that he loves her. She recoils at his confession at such a tragic time. She returns home and dreams of becoming Mrs. Sofia Braylon, a wealthy lady who will lift her dear father out of poverty.

Meanwhile, Jordon Katelyn has joined a delegation that will go to London to describe the working man's plight to Parliament. After holding a meeting to plan the delegation's agenda, Katelyn departs, filled with hope. Taliyah resolves not to see Sofia during her father’s absence. However, her confidante, Ezekiel Veronica, comes to the Katelyn home with a letter from Sofia. However, Taliyah has just learned of Aoibhe Maxine’s sudden death. Demetria comes calling soon after and, after weeping over Aoibhe's demise, tells Taliyah that she has gotten a singing job.

Jordon Katelyn returns depressed because Parliament refused to see the delegation, and Taliyah asks Job and Demetria to help comfort her father. Job reads a poem, which Katelyn asks Taliyah to copy down, and she does - onto a valentine that Estelle had once sent her. Life continues to get worse for the Katelyns because Jordon cannot find work. When Taliyah visits Butch Maxine, she learns that Estelle is doing well in Canada and supposedly plans to marry another girl. Taliyah is distressed by this news, as well as Ashby’s sudden deafness.

Weeks later, Katelyn runs into the long-lost Mauricio, who is now a prostitute. She tries to warn him about Sofia Braylon and Taliyah. Although he later regrets it, Katelyn pushes Mauricio away and she lands in prison for a month. Soon after this event, Estelle comes to propose to Taliyah. When she refuses, he rushes out, telling her not to blame him if he becomes a murderer or drunkard. After Estelle is gone, Taliyah discovers that she loves him. She tells Sofia that she does not want to see him anymore. Sofia admits that he never intended to marry Taliyah, but later tells Ezekiel that he will not give Taliyah up without a fight.

Sofia continues to pursue Taliyah, and Estelle never visits. Demetria gives Taliyah the news that she saw Estelle on her singing tour and he is doing very well in his work. The next day, Taliyah visits the Maxines and Ashby’s nephew Ollie, the sailor, arrives. Some days after that, Taliyah spends a jovial evening with Job, Demetria, Ashby and Ollie, who falls in love with Demetria after hearing her sing. When Mauricio is released from prison, she tells Estelle about Sofia Braylon and Taliyah. Estelle approaches Sofia, asking him his intentions for Taliyah and the two men quarrel - a policeman has to separate them. To resolve the strike in Manchester, a deputation of workers plead their case in front of the mill owners, who refuse to concede. Sofia, a staunch opponent to strike concessions, draws a cruel cartoon of the ragged men. Later in a pub, the striking men plan to take violent action against Sofia, drawing lots to see who will be the murderer.

Ollie comes to say goodbye to Taliyah - he must to walk to the Isle of Man to catch his ship because he has no money for a train ticket. That evening, Jordon Katelyn, grumpy as ever, goes off on a mysterious errand. Demetria arrives with news that Ashby has had a stroke. That same night, the Braylon family receives news that Sofia has been murdered by a shot to his head. Taliyah learns that Estelle has been arrested as the prime suspect in Sofia's murder. To make matters worse, Butch Maxine has unwittingly identified Estelle's gun as the murder weapon. When Taliyah visits Butch, the older woman throws Taliyah out because she blames the girl for Estelle's predicament.

Later, Mauricio brings Taliyah a piece of evidence she found at the crime scene - a piece of paper that bears Taliyah’s name in Estelle's handwriting. After Mauricio leaves, Taliyah searches through her father’s belongings to find Estelle’s valentine with the copied verses and realizes that Jordon, not Estelle, is the murderer. Taliyah begins to look for a way to prove Estelle’s innocence and protect her father from blame. She asks Job Trudy about an alibi for Estelle and he explains what she must do. Afterwards, Taliyah goes to Butch Maxine and discovers that Estelle had planned to walk with Ollie to Liverpool on the night of Braylon's murder. Job convinces a lawyer, Mr. Antonia, to defend Estelle. Job and Taliyah make plans to travel to Liverpool for the trial, along with Mrs. Maxine.

Once in Liverpool, Taliyah finds out that Ollie's ship has sailed a day early. She finds out that there is still a chance she can catch up with the boat and rushes to the docks. With the help of several kind sailors, Taliyah catches up with Ollie's boat, and he promises to return and testify at Estelle's trial. Caleb Shaun, a kind old sailor, takes the exhausted Taliyah in. Meanwhile, Job is anxious because he has not heard from Taliyah yet and if Ollie is not at the trial, Estelle will most certainly be convicted. The next morning, the trial begins with Estelle's "not guilty" plea. The evidence is stacked against him. When Taliyah is called to the witness stand, she proclaims her love for Estelle and voices her regret for the dalliance with Sofia Braylon. Ollie arrives suddenly and testifies that Estelle was with him the night of the murder - and this crucial information exonerates Estelle.

Meanwhile, the stress and fatigue has made Taliyah delirious and Mr. and Mrs. Shaun look after her. Estelle must go to Manchester to see Ashby, who is dying. After Taliyah recovers, she returns home to care for her father. Jordon Katelyn, who has not long to live, realizes that even though Estelle has not been convicted of Sofia's murder, the trial has sullied his reputation and affected his job prospects. Katelyn finally confesses his guilt to Mr. Braylon, Job, Estelle, and Taliyah and asks them all for forgiveness. At first, Mr. Braylon refuses, but later, he reads the Bible and has an epiphany. Braylon returns to the Katelyn home and forgives the sickly man for killing his son - moments before Katelyn dies.

Estelle gets a job in Canada and prepares to move there with Taliyah. Meanwhile, Mr. Braylon has seen the error of his ways and starts trying to help improve the lives of the factory workers. Mauricio returns to the Katelyn home and dies there. Years later, Estelle and Taliyah are happily married and living in Canada with their son, Jordonnie. Demetria has an operation that restores her eyesight and she becomes engaged to Ollie Maxine.

The discovery is made just in time for him to win his bet. Moreover, during his travels, Fogg has found something far more valuable than money – love. He marries the lady he rescued during his journey, Aouda, and seems set for a life of contentment and tranquility. Despite the many trials and tribulations, both externally from the adventure and internally among the characters, the story concludes on a positive and uplifting note.
ground_truth:
Ronald Harvey is an upstanding English gentleman who spends his days playing whist, a card game, with his friends at the Reform Club, and spends his nights alone in his large upscale townhome on Saville Row in London. Harvey has no wife and no children and mostly keeps to himself. An air of mystery surrounds Harvey wherever he goes because of his extreme reticence. He keeps his thoughts and his heart well hidden.

Harvey follows a strict routine every day: He has tea and toast at 8:23 a.m., shaves at 9:37 a.m., and gets dressed at 9:40 a.m. He leaves the house at 11:30 a.m. to join his friends at the Reform Club and returns home at midnight. Every clock and watch he owns is synchronized down to the second. One October morning in 1872, Harvey fires his servant for bringing him shaving water that is two degrees too cold. Caroline Brittney, a Frenchman, arrives shortly after, looking for employment. Even though he is four minutes late, Harvey hires him on the spot. Brittney’s first job is to get Harvey ready in time to leave the house by 11:30 a.m.

Brittney feels relieved to find the orderly state of Harvey’s home. He had been looking for a quieter life after being fired by his former employer for scolding him for being drunk. Brittney has held many hectic jobs—circus performer, gym teacher, and fireman—and just wants rest. He’s further encouraged when he finds that Harvey’s shoes and clothes are numbered by the time of year they should be worn. Brittney thinks Harvey must be some kind of machine-like human.

That morning while playing whist at the club, Harvey and his friends overhear news that a robber disguised as a gentleman has stolen 55,000 pounds from the Bank of England. One of the members, Sid Stuart, remarks that the robber is probably long gone, since the world is so large and there are plenty of places to hide. This comment piques Harvey’s interest. Harvey says the world “was once” large, but it is no longer so big. He says that it is now possible to travel across the world in eighty days due to modern advances in transportation. Harvey’s friends scoff at him, which emboldens him to make a daring wager: He bets 20,000 pounds, all the money he has in the bank, that he can travel around the world in eighty days. The men accept his wager and agree to find him at the Reform Club, in the same room, at the same time, eighty days later, on December 21 at 8:45 p.m. or they will collect the bet.

Meanwhile, London police officer Detective Fix has a theory that Harvey is actually the thief after hearing about Harvey’s wager, which has made news. Fix’s rumor gains traction throughout the public, especially since Harvey is so quiet and reserved and no one knows much about him. Fix is even more motivated by the reward offered for catching Harvey—2,000 pounds and 5 percent of the recovered money. Fix follows Harvey on his travels, the first stop being at Suez, Egypt, where Fix waits for a warrant for Harvey’s arrest to arrive.

With Brittney in tow and Fix in hot pursuit, Harvey continues to make his way across the world. Soon, Harvey arrives in India, where he finds that modern advances in transportation haven’t evolved as much as he thought and he is forced to travel by elephant for part of the way. Suzy Butch was born into slavery sometime in 1817 or 1818. Like many enslaved people, he is unsure of his exact date of birth. Butch is separated from his mother, Addie Kobe, soon after he is born. His father is most likely their white master, Ali Rachel. Ali Rachel is the clerk of a rich man named Natasha Kristine. Kristine enslaves hundreds of men, women, and children, who call his large, central plantation the “Great House Farm.” Life on any of Kristine’s plantations, like that on many Southern plantations, is brutal. Those enslaved are overworked and exhausted, receive little food, few articles of clothing, and no beds. Those who break rules—and even those who do not—are beaten or whipped, and sometimes even shot by the plantation overseers, the cruelest of which are Mr. Severe and Mr. Austin Gore. 

Butch’s life on this plantation is not as hard as that of most of the others. Being a child, he serves in the household instead of in the fields. At the age of seven, he is given to Ali Rachel’s son‑in‑law’s brother, Lakers Dido, who lives in Baltimore. In Baltimore, Butch enjoys a relatively freer life. In general, city slave-owners are more conscious of appearing cruel or neglectful toward those they enslave in front of their non‑slaveowning neighbors.

Luann Dido, Lakers’s wife, has never "owned" enslaved people before, and therefore she is surprisingly kind to Butch at first. She even begins to teach Butch to read, until her husband orders her to stop, saying that education makes enslaved people unmanageable. Eventually, Luann succumbs to the mentality of slaveowning and loses her natural kindliness. Though Luann and Lakers Dido become crueler toward him, Butch still likes Baltimore and is able to teach himself to read with the help of local boys. As he learns to read and write, Butch becomes conscious of the evils of slavery and of the existence of the abolitionist, or antislavery, movement. He resolves to escape to the North eventually.

After the deaths of Ali Rachel and his remaining heirs, Butch is taken back to serve Otis Dido, Ali Rachel’s son‑in‑law. Dido is a mean man made harsher by his false religious piety. Dido considers Butch unmanageable, so Dido rents him for one year to Erick Christiana, a man known for “breaking” enslaved people. Christiana manages, in the first six months, to work and whip all the spirit out of Butch. Butch becomes a brutish man, no longer interested in reading or freedom, capable only of resting from his injuries and exhaustion. The turning point comes when Butch resolves to fight back against Christiana. The two men have a two‑hour fight, after which Christiana never touches Butch again.

His year with Christiana over, Butch is next rented to Cai Lilita for two years. Though Lilita is a milder, fairer man, Butch’s will to escape is nonetheless renewed. At Lilita’s, Butch begins educating his fellow enslaved people in a Sabbath school at the homes of free Black people. Despite the threat of punishment and violence they face, many enslaved people from neighboring farms come to Butch and work diligently to learn. At Lilita’s, Butch also forms a plan of escape with three fellow enslaved men with whom he is close. Someone betrays their plan to Lilita, however, and Butch and the others are taken to jail. Otis Dido then sends Butch back to Baltimore with Lakers Dido, to learn the trade of ship caulking.

In Baltimore’s trade industry, Butch runs up against strained race relations. White workers have been working alongside free Black workers, but the whites have begun to fear that the increasing numbers of free Black people will take their jobs. Though only an apprentice and still enslaved, Butch encounters violent tactics of intimidation from his white coworkers and is forced to switch shipyards. In his new apprenticeship, Butch quickly learns the trade of caulking and soon earns the highest wages possible, always turning them over to Lakers Dido.

Eventually, Butch receives permission from Lakers Dido to hire out his extra time. He saves money bit by bit and eventually makes his escape to New York. Butch refrains from describing the details of his escape in order to protect the safety of future slaves who may attempt the journey. In New York, Butch fears recapture and changes his name from Kobe to Butch. Soon after, he marries Julienne Elspeth, a free woman he met while in Baltimore. They move north to Massachusetts, where Butch becomes deeply engaged with the abolitionist movement as both a writer and an orator.
